docs.lead_paragraph: Congress gave final approval tonight to a $1.87 trillion Republican budget outline for next year that includes tax reductions and cuts in many domestic programs, setting up an election-year showdown with Democrats over how the nation should put its current prosperity to use. Even before the House and Senate passed the measure in largely party-line votes, President Clinton said the Republican approach risked squandering what he called ''this magic moment of possibility.''

docs.lead_paragraph: House Republicans began rallying support today for their plan to offer insurance coverage of prescription drug costs to all 39 million Medicare beneficiaries, even as the White House called the proposal ''a major disappointment.'' AARP, a leading voice for older Americans, cautiously welcomed the proposal but noted that the Republicans had offered only an outline, without providing details of how the plan would work.

headline.main: G.O.P. in House Offers Medicare Drug Plan

docs.lead_paragraph: Last week he was an environmentalist. Now he's a health care reformer. Who knows what rewriting of reality is yet to come? George W. Bush's first speech on health care was delivered in Cleveland on Tuesday.
docs.abstract: Bob Herbert Op-Ed article notes Gov George W Bush is giving campaign speeches promising low-income Americans access to high-quality health care if he is elected; says Texas has been notoriously backward when it comes to health care, and Bush never made speech on subject before becoming presidential candidate; says Bush's choice for state health commissioner, Dr William R Archer III, minimizes importance of fact that two-fifths of state's poor children lack health insurance; claims Bush appears to be clueless about health care, both unaware and unconcerned
docs.snippet: Last week he was an environmentalist. Now he's a health care reformer. Who knows what rewriting of reality is yet to come?    George W. Bush's first speech on health care was delivered in Cleveland on Tuesday.

docs.lead_paragraph: In his harshest and most comprehensive critique of his Republican rival to date, Vice President Al Gore today questioned Gov. George W. Bush's self-anointment as a ''reformer with results'' and said that if Texas was Mr. Bush's model for what he would do as president, he had no credibility. ''He keeps saying he's a reformer with results,'' Mr. Gore said in a speech to the American Society of Newspaper Editors. ''Where are the results? They're not in Texas.''

headline.main: Gore Challenges Bush Credibility on Policy Speeches

docs.abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore questions Gov George W Bush's self-anointment as 'reformer with results' in his harshest and most comprehensive critique of his Republican rival to date; says if Texas is Bush's model for what he would do as president, he has no credibility; claims Bush pretends to care about issues like health care, education and environment but that his record in Texas shows he has done little on those fronts; speech seems to betray some concerns in Gore campaign about Bush's potential to make inroads with traditional Democratic voters and suburban swing voters; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For the second day in a row, Gov. George W. Bush kept his campaign focused on health care, touring a community clinic and proposing to spend an additional $4.3 billion over five years to expand health care services to the needy in the inner cities and remote rural communities. The Texas governor visited the Grace Hill Neighborhood Health Center, located in a traditionally Democratic area of Missouri. He then made his announcement this morning flanked by doctors and nurses, black and white, creating another campaign tableau showing him with members of minority groups.

headline.main: Bush Proposes New Spending For More Health Care Services

docs.abstract: Gov George W Bush focuses his campaign on health care for second straight day; tours community clinic in St Louis, Mo, and proposes to spend additional $4.3 billion over five years to expand health care services to needy in inner cities and remote rural communities; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I was struck by Dr. Edward Flaschner's tale of the two doctors' offices -- Dr. Harried and Dr. Relaxed (letter, April 11) -- and his assertion that doctors' interests and those of their patients pretty well mesh. I am definitely seeing the relaxed doctor. I get excellent regular care for a chronic condition. He asks concerned questions, writes out a prescription (this takes no more than 15 minutes), and he charges $150, roughly $10 a minute. It is the going rate, and I can afford it. I like him; I'm not really complaining. If he's not Marcus Welby, he's close.
docs.abstract: Tessa Joseph letter comments on Dr Edward Flaschner's April 11 letter asserting that doctors' interests and those of their patients pretty well mesh

Bush delivered yesterday at the West Side Ecumenical Ministry in Cleveland, as reported on his Web site: At the edges of affluent communities, there are those living in prosperity's shadow. The same economy that is a miracle for millions of Americans is a mystery for millions as well. Americans who live in a world above welfare's assistance, but beneath prosperity's promise.

docs.lead_paragraph: House Republicans said today that their proposal for Medicare coverage of prescription drugs, to be announced this week, would use private insurance subsidized by the government to help pay drug costs for millions of people who are elderly or disabled. The announcement will be a milestone on the road to such coverage, a firm proposal by leaders of the majority party in the House that says how they would spend up to $40 billion over the next five years.

headline.main: G.O.P. Drug Coverage Plan Is to Include Private Insurers

docs.abstract: House Republicans say they will propose using voluntary private insurance subsidized by government to help pay drug costs for elderly and others on Medicare; main subsidy would be indirect, with government paying most of costs for small number of beneficiaries with highest drug expenses, so insurers can charge lower premiums to everyone else; photo (M)
docs.snippet: House Republicans said today that their proposal for Medicare coverage of prescription drugs, to be announced this week, would use private insurance subsidized by the government to help pay drug costs for millions of people who are elderly or...

docs.lead_paragraph: In a slap to the pharmaceutical industry and a rebuke to Congress, the Maine Legislature on Tuesday became the first in the country to approve a bill that would clamp sweeping price controls on medications sold in the state. The Act to Establish Fairer Prescription Drug Prices would immediately establish a pricing board to set suggested lower prices. If the prices did not fall, then as of Oct. 1, 2001, the board would mandate that all drugs sold in the state cost no more than they would in Canada.

headline.main: Maine Will Cap Drug Prices With a Groundbreaking Law

docs.abstract: Maine Legislature becomes first in nation to approve bill to cut prices of prescription drugs sold in state; would require that drugs cost no more in Maine than in Canada if prices do not fall by Oct 2001; Vermont Senate has passed similar bill and sent it to House; New England states have formed coalition to try to present united front on drug prices; drug industry scores bill (M)
